When Utah authorities began searching for Rossi using a decade-old DNA rape kit, leading to the identification and subsequent charges against him.
The date an online obituary falsely claimed Rossi died, which later became a key part of the investigation into his alleged faking of death.
When Rossi was extradited to Utah after being arrested in Scotland, following a protracted legal battle.

The period during which Rossi was identified, arrested, extradited, and sentenced, highlighting a long and complex legal journey.

keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008 and sentenced to between five years and life in prison after appearing to fake his death and flee the U.S.
Rossi's legal name is Nicholas Alahverdian, and he used multiple aliases over the years to evade capture, including posing as Arthur Knight, an Irish orphan.
He was identified through a decade-old DNA rape kit as part of Utah’s efforts to clear its rape kit backlog.
An online obituary falsely claimed Rossi died in 2020, prompting suspicion and investigation into whether he was actually dead.
Rossi was arrested in Scotland in 2024 after hospital staff recognized his tattoos from an Interpol notice, and was extradited to Utah.
The victim testified that Rossi pressured her to pay for dates and car repairs, took on debt for engagement rings, and raped her in his bedroom.
He is described as a 'serial abuser of women' and a 'flight risk' by prosecutors, and has a history of evading legal accountability.
Rossi's first conviction was in August 2025, with a second sentencing scheduled in November 2025 for a separate rape case.
Utah law allows prison sentences to be given as a range, and in this case, the range is five years to life, determined by a parole board.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man whose legal name is Nicholas Alahverdian, was convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008 and sentenced to between five and life in prison after a long investigation that revealed he had faked his death and fled the U.S. He was identified through a decade-old DNA rape kit, and a false online obituary claiming his death in 2020 raised suspicions. Authorities in Rhode Island and Utah, along with Interpol, helped track him down after he was arrested in Scotland in 2024 due to recognition of his tattoos. Rossi, who used aliases like Arthur Knight and a Brown University tattoo, has a history of evading justice and previous sex-related charges. Prosecutors argued he is a flight risk and serial abuser, while the victim described the trauma of the attacks. The case reflects broader issues in sexual assault accountability, DNA backlog investigations, and international fugitive recovery.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
